name: Quadratic Formula
explanation: The quadratic formula solves any quadratic equation of the form ax² + bx + c = 0. The ± symbol means there are typically two solutions. The expression under the square root (b² - 4ac) is called the discriminant. If it's positive, there are two real solutions; if zero, one solution; if negative, two complex solutions.
proof: Start with ax² + bx + c = 0. Divide by a: x² + (b/a)x + c/a = 0. Complete the square: x² + (b/a)x = -c/a. Add (b/2a)² to both sides: x² + (b/a)x + (b/2a)² = -c/a + (b/2a)². Left side is (x + b/2a)². Right side: -c/a + b²/4a² = (-4ac + b²)/4a² = (b² - 4ac)/4a². Take square root: x + b/2a = ±√(b² - 4ac)/2a. Solve for x: x = -b/2a ± √(b² - 4ac)/2a = (-b ± √(b² - 4ac))/2a.
